content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player who is comfortable with taking risks, I would analyze this game strategically to maximize my expected payoff over the 75 rounds.

In each round, choosing R has a higher potential reward (45$) compared to choosing B (20$). However, there is also a greater risk of getting 0$ if my opponent chooses B while I choose R. On the other hand, choosing B always guarantees a minimum payout of 20$.

Since the game consists of 75 rounds, and we don't have information about our opponent's strategy, it is reasonable to assume that they might choose either R or B randomly or use some strategy to exploit ours. To maximize my expected payoff, I would want to minimize the number of times I end up with 0$ (by choosing R only when my opponent also chooses R) and maximize the number of times I get 45$ or 20$.

To achieve this goal, I could choose a mixed strategy where I pick R about two-thirds of the time and B for the remaining one-third. This way, if my opponent also picks a similar strategy, we will both choose R more frequently than B, and I can expect to get 45$ more often than 0$. Since I still want to maximize my payoff, I would lean slightly towards choosing R more often than B, given that choosing R has a higher potential reward.

However, since the game involves an anonymous opponent, there is no way for me to know their strategy or adjust mine in response. Therefore, I can only assume they will play optimally as well, and my best bet would be to choose a mixed strategy that leans towards R but doesn't completely neglect B.

In conclusion, I would likely choose the letter 'R' more often than 'B', but not exclusively so, to maximize my expected payoff over the 75 rounds.

{R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since I have already played R in the previous round and my opponent chose B, they earned 40$ while I got 0$.

In this new round, I will adjust my strategy slightly to account for the fact that my opponent has chosen B once before. To maximize my expected payoff over the remaining rounds, I will lean even more towards choosing R to increase the chances of getting a higher reward when we both pick R in future rounds. However, I still want to minimize the risk of ending up with 0$ again.

Given these considerations, I would choose R in this new round as well. This choice increases the likelihood that my opponent will also pick R in the next few rounds, since they may start to adjust their strategy to match mine, and we can both earn more rewards together.
